posts.name:
Anna Mykheieva
Anna Mykheieva
posts.content:
My Team is Not My Family

I recently read about how Netflix conducted an internal survey and let go of employees who considered their colleagues ‚Äúfamily.‚Äù And‚Äîdeep down‚ÄîI agreed with this decision. I‚Äôd actually be concerned if my team felt like family to me.

Sounds harsh, right? But let‚Äôs break it down.

I deeply value every member at my workplace. We joke around in internal chats and personal messages, check in on each other, have a blast at corporate events, and communicate openly. In every project I‚Äôve led, I‚Äôve always prioritized creating a great atmosphere, and it remains one of my main focuses Ô∏è

That being said, I don‚Äôt see my partners and employees as family. Instead, we‚Äôre more like a sports team striving for a common goal‚Äîlike an Olympic squad.
Let me explain from a psychological perspective. Relationships are often built around fulfilling certain needs.
What kind of needs might someone who looks for ‚Äúfamily‚Äù in their team be trying to fulfill?
‚ñ´Ô∏è unconditional love and acceptance
‚ñ´Ô∏è support
‚ñ´Ô∏è safety
‚ñ´Ô∏è stability and predictability (family is forever)
Let‚Äôs ignore the obvious contradiction here‚Äîno one in a family owes anyone anything, yet a CEO is expected to pay salaries . Instead, let‚Äôs think‚Äîcan I truly meet those needs?

No, because I‚Äôm building my brand.
For comparison, my needs as an entrepreneur and leader are entirely different‚Äînot family-oriented:
 high net profit
 satisfied clients
 efficient use of resources
To achieve this, I need results and the unique strengths of each team member. I have to set goals and tasks, require KPI fulfillment, enforce deadlines and agreements.
This brings us to another issue with seeing a team as family‚Äîthe development of strong secondary emotional ties.
If person isn‚Äôt performing well, and I‚Äôm emotionally attached to them, it will be harder for me to explain what's wrong. But‚Ä¶ this paradise wouldn‚Äôt last long anyway, because inefficient work leads to financial losses, and the business would eventually collapse.

So, what‚Äôs my approach?
I advocate for a partnership-based and respectful attitude to team.
What are your thoughts and feelings about this attitude toward a team?

(P.S. Bruno is helping me to manage my work  )

comments.commentText:
Not every work chat needs to feel like a Thanksgiving dinner Anna 
Keep it pro, 
keep it moving.
Ali Haider thank you a lot

Treating teams as partners ensures accountability, growth, and mutual respect, which is key to long-term success. 

Building a brand needs clarity in relationships‚Äîfamilies are forever, but teams evolve with goals!

posts.name:
Jeff Gibson
Jeff Gibson
posts.content:
This week, there have been lots of discussions about hiring fewer engineers because they are x% more effective (because of AI). That seems odd to me; shouldn't you hire more?

Engineers should be able to generate a multiple of their salary in ARR; if they are 30% more effective, they can generate 30% more revenue, making it even easier to justify hiring more engineers.

If this isn't the case, problems are likely brewing.

Of course, adding new features isn't the only way to generate revenue. However, sales and marketing can only effectively sell the product you actually have built.

comments.commentText:
Does market cap increase simply because productivity increases? 

I'm going to oversimplify here:

Let's pick say IT services, a company of 100 creates 1000 IT-support requests per a year or their staff is bottlenecked.

If I'm running a firm dedicated to serving my clients needs, and my tech professionals can solve 30 percent more, unless the rate of issues increase, I need less head count to deliver my services and collect.

In the case of tech support, if my clients are now running leaner, and able to self-serveve more often with LLMs, that market cap begins to collapse.

Now if I did want to maintain my headcount, I could potentially pick up more clients with that surplus, but my competing firms are also acting more effective.(unless I have some proprietary system not generally available to break symmetry)

This is really where marketing comes into play if we want to avoid an economic spiral to the bottom.

As LLMs collapse existing markets, and I wanna keep my good people employed, I could now branch into other markets, for example data-backup services. However secondary existing markets are also likely collapsing by the same forces.

The best solution to the current situation would be to grow new markets.

Eric C in the example of Salesforce who made news last week, it's a much better example of this trap because they are a product company.

The idea that no further investment in R&D is needed because of AI and all that's needed to make more money is hiring 1000 sales people to sell more AI is probably the best message that can be delivered to shareholders. Of course it's entirely short term as eventually the tech debt piles up and they already have a mountain of it to start!

In the case of a services based company you can charge more per hour given more output, charge per outcome and deliver more outcomes, or have more junior people ramp faster which of course means less time from seniors and higher billable rates. That being said, the services market in most segments is over saturated so you're right that they need to offer more or expand.

Eric C In the long run, yes, market cap increases with productivity, but investors are rarely concerned with long-run economics, and most companies prioritize pandering to investors over all other practices.

Fully agree. Most peoples' eyes glaze over when I ask them about profitability, ROI, and what part of an application is the most profitable, and what's losing money.

WHY ARE YOUR EYES GLAZING OVER?!! THIS IS THE MOST CRUCIAL QUESTION FOR YOUR COMPANY!!! If you don't know the answer, whether you choose JavaScript over Ruby* is irrelevant!

* (FYI, it's JavaScript...go with JavaScript)
Jordan H. 1000%! People (maybe not?) be surprised by how many companies make engineering decisions without thinking about ROI/profitability.

I now tell all good Indian startups to try to sell in outside Indian markets. 

Because India has only mass consumers but hardly any consumer loyalty and higher spend. No business can grow on such type of consumer base.

If your product is really good, then try to sell it outside India and see how good it really is.

posts.name:
Colby Wegter
Colby Wegter
posts.content:
How we took our agency from $80K months to $208K months (without cold outreach or ads):

You have a lead problem, right?

It's a problem, sure. But it's not THE problem.

So what is it?

You're not taking advantage of your existing clients.

We weren't either. It took us over 5 years to get to $1M per year.

Then we got to $2.5M per year in 12 months.

Here's what we did:

[1] The Website

We sold SEO but weren't using it ourselves.

‚Üí Gettable keywords
‚Üí Geo + Service pages
‚Üí Long-form blogs

We doubled our investment on our core service for ourselves and it worked.

[2] Maximum Leverage Clients

Not all clients are created equal. So we didn't treat them that way.

Organized clients into four categories:

‚Üí Low paying, Low maintenance
‚Üí Low paying, High maintenance
‚Üí High paying, High maintenance
‚Üí High paying, Low maintenance

Each category got an action plan.

More efficiency for low-leverage clients. More upsells to high-leverage clients.

[3] Beta Offers

Speaking of upsells, we wanted them to be painless and profitable.

Beta Offers solved that.

‚Üí One call
‚Üí One slide deck
‚Üí Multiple clients upsold for 3X their original investment

When:

‚Üí Your website is your #1 salesperson
‚Üí Each client has a clear action plan
‚Üí Your best clients invest more

How many leads do you need to hit 7 figures and beyond?

Jus' sayin'.

Straightforward is sexy. I break all this down in detail in my newsletter:

comments.commentText: When you take the time to craft smart BETA upsells. Your time prospecting or doing outreach shrinks. Much better to keep selling to people who already trust you over people who don't
Great point maximizing clients is everything

posts.name:
Jen Blandos
Jen Blandos
posts.content:
Netflix‚Äôs talent strategy: 

Revolutionary? Or a recipe for burnout?

Netflix doesn‚Äôt see teams as families - it sees them as professional sports teams.

Here‚Äôs how their approach works:

1Ô∏è‚É£ The Keeper Test
Managers ask themselves two simple questions:

‚ÄúIf [X] wanted to leave, would I fight to keep them?‚Äù
‚ÄúKnowing what I know today, would I rehire them?‚Äù
If the answer is no, it‚Äôs ‚Äúfairer to part ways quickly.‚Äù
‚Ü≥ But Netflix evaluates the whole record‚Äîshort-term mistakes don‚Äôt cost someone their job.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Teammates, Not Siblings
Families are about unconditional love.
Sports teams? They‚Äôre built to win.
‚Ü≥ Netflix focuses on performance and accountability, even if it means replacing beloved team members.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Radical Autonomy
No holiday policy.
No expense policy.
No micro-management.
‚Ü≥ Netflix trusts its staff to make decisions, rewarding self-motivation and responsibility.

But this approach isn‚Äôt for everyone.
Netflix‚Äôs culture thrives on risk, experimentation, and resilience - but for those who need stability, it may feel too intense.

‚¨áÔ∏è Could Netflix‚Äôs strategy work in your organisation?
Would it push your team to perform at their best - or leave them feeling burnt out and demotivated?
 Follow me, Jen Blandos, for actionable tips on business, entrepreneurship, and workplace well-being.
Ô∏è Think this could spark ideas for a team you know? Share this post to give others more inspiration.

comments.commentText:
I think it‚Äôs totally an individual‚Äôs preference and what they want. 

Definitely a burnout for folks not cut for this game. Those who are passionate and love working in such high pressure environments it‚Äôs a paradise.

Which one is you? ;)
Arun Narayan It really depends on personal resilience and passion for the challenge.

posts.content:
Be very choosy when deciding on people with whom to share and what to share. You may give your weapon to them to hurt you.

Be very careful.

comments.commentText: Your insight on the importance of discerning whom to trust resonates deeply. In our interconnected world, safeguarding our vulnerabilities is crucial to maintaining our well-being. Thank you for sharing such a powerful reminder.
